lessons.title: Intro
lessons.interactiveContent:
We use JSX to create HTML-like code in JavaScript when using React.
It looks and feels like HTML, but itâ€™s actually JavaScript.

JSX is so helpful because it makes our components more readable and familiar.

Make sure to pick <h1>, followed by </h1>.

lessons.title: Intro - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
JSX uses syntax that is almost identical to HTML. HTML elements are created in JSX as they are in HTML.

Create the opening h1 tag to return an h1 element in the App component.

Make sure to type <h1>.

lessons.title: Intro - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can only return one element when creating a component using JSX.

However, we can add multiple elements inside a div element and return the div element.

Make sure to pick <div>, followed by </div>.

lessons.title: Intro - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can either directly return a tag or use parentheses () to return a multiple-line JSX snippet.

If the JSX spans multiple lines, itâ€™s better to wrap it in parentheses for clarity.

Make sure to pick (, followed by ).

lessons.title: Intro - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we return a single line, we can just add the JSX after the return statement to return it.

Make sure to pick return, followed by <p>, and finally </p>.

lessons.title: Intro - Copy - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Even though JSX looks like HTML, itâ€™s actually JavaScript under the hood. Using JavaScript to define our layout comes with some benefits.

Like in plain JavaScript, we can perform calculations in JSX.

Make sure to pick 5, followed by +, and finally 5.

lessons.title: Intro - Copy  - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Any such embedded expressions need to go between curly braces {}.

Make sure to pick {, followed by }.

lessons.title: Intro - Copy  - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
But there's much more than simple calculation. JSX gives us the full power of JavaScript, and we can also reference variables inside JSX.

For example, we can display variables inside an embedded expression.

Make sure to pick name, followed by name.

lessons.title: sadfsd
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can perform calculations, reference variables, or use any other valid JavaScript expression inside the curly braces.

Define the variable score and use it inside the embedded expression.

Make sure to pick score, followed by score.

lessons.title: Question: JSX Markup
lessons.interactiveContent:
What kind of syntax does JSX use for its elements?

< and >, similar to HTML[ and ], similar to arrays

< and >, similar to HTML.

lessons.title: sadfsd - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use the variable number inside the embedded expression.

Make sure to pick number.

lessons.title: Question: JSX Markup Pt. 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
What kind of JSX helps us create a heading that reads Help Wanted?

<h1>Help Wanted</h1>{Help Wanted}

<h1>Help Wanted</h1>.

lessons.title: Question: Embedded Expressions
lessons.interactiveContent:
What do we use embedded expressions for?

To insert JavaScript and JSX in other JSX elementsTo create a new JSX element

To insert JavaScript and JSX in other JSX elements.

lessons.title: Example: Embedded Expression
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use an embedded expression to ensure that the value of name displays within the h1 element.

Make sure to pick <h1>, followed by {name}, and finally </h1>.

lessons.title: Question: JSX Markup - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
What kind of syntax do we use for embedded expressions?

{ and }< and >

{ and }.

lessons.title: Intro - Copy  - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
In the Welcome component, display the value of the name variable using an embedded expression.

Make sure to type {name}.

lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent:
When using JSX, we can use all the tags we already know from regular HTML, including <div>, <h1>, <p>, and <footer>.

Make sure to pick <div> followed by <h1> and then <p>, <footer>.

lessons.title: Lesson #1 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Some elements are self-closing, which means they only have a single tag that ends with a slash /.

Unlike HTML, JSX requires any self-closing tag to end with a slash /.

Make sure to pick /, followed by /, and finally /.

lessons.title: Lesson #1 - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can also store JSX inside a variable.

This is useful when you want to write JSX in some part of your code and then refer to it somewhere else in a more readable way.

Make sure to pick const, followed by nameHeader.

lessons.title: Lesson #1 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can also reference other JSX elements using a JSX expression with curly braces {}.

Make sure to pick {, followed by }.

lessons.title: Lesson #1 -  - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
To include multiple JSX expressions within a single component, we need to use curly braces for each expression.

Make sure to pick {, followed by }, and finally age.

lessons.title: Lesson #1 -  - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can even use embedded expressions to pass values into a JSX element's attributes.

Use the value of theÂ url variableÂ for theÂ srcÂ attribute of the img element.

Make sure to pick {, followed by url, and finally }.

lessons.title: Lesson #1 -  - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent: Embedded expressions are a powerful tool in our React toolkit and allow for nifty interactions with your app's user interface.

lessons.title: Example: Attributes - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Finish the code to make the React app render as expected.

Make sure to pick {name}, followed by {url}.

lessons.title: CHANGE
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which attributes does the input element have?

id, type, and valuetype, value, and input

id, type, and value.

lessons.title: CHANGE
lessons.interactiveContent:
Complete the JSX with the correct closing tag.

Make sure to pick < followed by / and then span, >.

lessons.title: Question: Variables
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which one of these variable declarations is correct?

const headerconst text

const header.

lessons.title: Example: Variables
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a variable so that the code displays ON SALE.

Make sure to pick const followed by header and then =, <h4>, ON, SALE, </h4>.

lessons.title: Example: Attributes - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use embedded expressions to add the values of the variables where they belong.

Make sure to pick { followed by name and then }, {, url, }.

lessons.title: Example: Attributes - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Define the name variable and use it inside the JSX with an embedded expression.

Make sure to pick name followed by { and then name, }.
